subject: Your Microsoft storage is almost full

What really causes night sweats, how cutting back on sugar changes the body, and more
body:

And how to make them stop.

subject: The 10-Point: Wall Street‚Äôs ADHD pill problem; hunting for the Assad fortune; bitcoin‚Äôs big new believers
body:
Your guide to the WSJ‚Äôs exclusive reporting and analysis.               Is this email difficult to read? View in browser   https://10point.cmail19.com/t/d-e-seudyk-dhllatrhk-f/                                                                                                   

Sponsored By

   



‚úèÔ∏è Some young Wall Street bankers say they have a drug problem: Namely, that they can‚Äôt handle their huge workloads  without ADHD pills [https://www.wsj.com/finance/banking/young-banker-finance-adhd-medication-adderall-d578a16f]. In Syria, the collapse of the Assad dynasty has kicked off a  hunt for the massive fortune [https://www.wsj.com/world/middle-east/the-hunt-for-the-assad-dynastys-missing-billions-begins-715e7052] the family accumulated over a half century of despotic rule. And American seniors are flocking to  one part of South Carolina [https://www.wsj.com/real-estate/luxury-homes/myrtle-beach-home-buyers-65-older-e949aa4c] faster than anywhere else in the U.S.

Emma Tucker

Editor in Chief, The Wall Street Journal

TODAY'S HEADLINES

1

A brush with a Russian ship in the Baltic points to a new flashpoint in the intensifying  shadow war between NATO and Moscow [https://www.wsj.com/world/europe/brush-with-russia-in-baltic-points-to-new-flashpoint-in-nato-moscow-shadow-war-08b5b182].  The U.S. is in direct  contact with the Islamist rebel group [https://www.wsj.com/world/middle-east/washington-in-direct-talks-with-the-former-al-qaeda-faction-that-toppled-assad-ddba4a61] that led the overthrow of Bashar al-Assad in Syria, and is pressing for a swift transition to avert chaos.  ABC agreed to pay $15 million to settle a  defamation lawsuit against George Stephanopoulos [https://www.wsj.com/business/media/abc-news-to-pay-15-million-to-settle-donald-trump-defamation-lawsuit-f1b8812d], who wrongly said Donald Trump was found liable for rape.  Apple is preparing to launch  thinner, foldable iPhones [https://www.wsj.com/tech/apple-thin-iphone-foldable-computer-plans-dbb4286c] in an attempt to revive growth after years of offering largely incremental upgrades.  India‚Äôs novel  efforts to fight deadly air pollution [https://www.wsj.com/world/india/india-air-pollution-short-term-solutions-5815e58d], such as antismog guns and drones, are falling short.

FROM THE MARKETS

2

Companies are mounting a campaign to  soften Trump‚Äôs proposed tariffs [https://www.wsj.com/economy/trade/trump-tariff-plan-business-lobbying-8f02ccea], but the president-elect isn‚Äôt budging.  üéß Podcast: Robinhood CEO Vlad Tenev joins WSJ‚Äôs Take On the Week to talk about  the rise and future of retail investing [https://www.wsj.com/podcasts/take-on-the-week/is-the-yolo-trade-back-robinhood-ceo-vlad-tenev-weighs-in/a61ea082-d937-4ee5-8197-755577a64416].

READ IT HERE FIRST

3

Young bankers are relying on stimulants to work through the day and night.

Stories of Wall Street workers blowing cash on drugs and nightlife are well known, with cocaine a favorite during the 1980s. These days, drugs are more a tool to  boost performance on the job [https://www.wsj.com/finance/banking/young-banker-finance-adhd-medication-adderall-d578a16f]. Especially for entry-level bankers, prescriptions for stimulants such as Adderall and other ADHD drugs have become commonplace, reports Alexander Saeedy. Some workers say they‚Äôve developed dependencies and social problems because of their overuse of these drugs. The feeling that the jobs can‚Äôt be done without stimulants comes as Wall Street is under fire for pushing junior bankers to take on dangerous workloads.





4

The hunt for the Assad dynasty‚Äôs missing billions is on.            

PHOTO: ALI HAJ SULEIMAN/GETTY IMAGES



In the decades after patriarch Hafez al-Assad seized power in 1970, the family built  a global network of investments [https://www.wsj.com/world/middle-east/the-hunt-for-the-assad-dynastys-missing-billions-begins-715e7052], including real estate in Russia, boutique hotels in Vienna and a private jet located in Dubai, report Benoit Faucon and Rory Jones. The fortune‚Äôs exact size and distribution isn‚Äôt known, but a 2022 State Department report estimated it could be worth between $1 billion and $12 billion. It said the money was often obtained through state monopolies and drug dealing, and partly reinvested beyond the reach of international law. Lawyers hope to recover assets for the Syrian people‚Äîbut the chase will likely be long and difficult, if efforts to track down the fortunes of Saddam Hussein and Moammar Gadhafi are any guide.



Relive some of Silicon Valley‚Äôs biggest flops.

Sign up for 8 Epic Startup Failures [https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://10point.cmail19.com/t/d-l-sejjdt-idhliuvdk-a/__;!!F0Stn7g!Gtkpm-w-KjEfx4QZ3wdE_cyssQ58lOGOYM2IHdYHKaKVDZ7fI3OFndCTQBX4QQkSux6mcc4F6hVMj-CKiCpfvQ$], a free limited email series that chronicles 40+ years of spectacular flameouts, with details from the Journal‚Äôs coverage.



              CONTENT FROM: Northern Trust          What strategies are business owners pursuing for 2025?   [http://pubads.g.doubleclick.net/gampad/clk?id=6727974124&iu=/2]

In this year‚Äôs Business Owner Benchmark report, we talked to owners of businesses with an average annual revenue of $50m+. Read our report to find out their plans for the year ahead ‚Äî from investing in AI to planning for sale or succession ‚Äî and what strategies they‚Äôre implementing.

Read our report [http://pubads.g.doubleclick.net/gampad/clk?id=6727974124&iu=/2]



EXPERT TAKE

5

Q: Wall Street titans once thought bitcoin was a fad. What are they saying now?

Bitcoin took some 15 years from creation to reach $100,000, and it experienced feverish rallies and spectacular crashes along the way. Reporter Vicky Ge Huang wrote about how some of Wall Street‚Äôs  biggest luminaries [https://www.wsj.com/finance/currencies/bitcoin-dimon-fink-griffin-buffet-dalio-crypto-af5af1a5] have‚Äîor haven‚Äôt‚Äîchanged their thinking about the cryptocurrency over time.

A: With prices rising and crypto companies flush with cash, some of the biggest banks and asset managers on Wall Street are trying to capitalize on the resurgence. Others still shun what they see as a speculative bubble.

JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon, who called the token a fraud in 2017, has maintained personal skepticism even as his bank has agreed to facilitate trading in ETFs that hold bitcoin. More recently, he called bitcoin a useless ‚Äúpet rock.‚Äù  BlackRock CEO Larry Fink, who was once a proud skeptic of bitcoin, changed his opinion and has described it as a legitimate asset.  Citadel chief Ken Griffin called his prior dismissal of bitcoin ‚Äúa mistake,‚Äù but says he still questions the economic utility of the virtual currency.  Berkshire Hathaway‚Äôs Warren Buffett has been a longstanding critic of bitcoin‚Äîand doesn‚Äôt appear to have budged.  Bridgewater Associates founder Ray Dalio, who dismissed bitcoin as ‚Äúa speculative bubble‚Äù in 2017, changed his tune and called it ‚Äúone hell of an invention‚Äù in 2021.

SEE THE STORY

6

MSNBC and CNN are fighting to dig out of a postelection ratings hole.                                                       

As viewers flock to Fox News in the wake of Trump‚Äôs election win,  ratings for MSNBC and CNN have tumbled [https://www.wsj.com/business/media/msnbc-cnn-fox-news-ratings-trump-83a883f5]. The declines are far worse than in 2016. MSNBC averaged 603,000 prime-time viewers from the day after last month‚Äôs election through Dec. 8, down more than half from the network‚Äôs year-to-date average through the election, according to Nielsen data. CNN was down 46%, to 401,000 viewers. Meanwhile, Fox was up 12%, averaging about 2.7 million viewers.

HAPPENING THIS WEEK

7

Tuesday: The Commerce Department reports November retail sales figures at 8:30 a.m. The Federal Reserve reports November industrial production figures at 9:15 a.m. ET.  Wednesday: The Commerce Department releases new residential construction data for November at 8:30 a.m. The Federal Reserve releases a policy statement and new economic projections at 2 p.m. ET.  Thursday: The National Association of Realtors reports existing-home sales for November at 10 a.m. ET. The Labor Department reports weekly jobless claims at 8:30 a.m. ET.

THE NUMBER

8

          68%          

The share of Americans who said large companies had a negative effect on the direction of the country in a January 2024 Pew Research Center online survey, down slightly from 71% in 2022, but up from 61% in 2019. Frustration with big business recently boiled over into support from some for Luigi Mangione, the alleged killer of UnitedHealthcare‚Äôs CEO. Yet, in a sign of  the complexity of Americans‚Äô relationship with corporate power [https://www.wsj.com/business/untangling-americas-love-hate-relationship-with-corporate-power-6d415af4], business titans such as Warren Buffett are widely admired for their drive.

AND FINALLY...

9

Older Americans are moving to Myrtle Beach faster than anywhere else.

On South Carolina‚Äôs Atlantic Ocean coast is the Myrtle Beach area. The 60-mile stretch, called the Grand Strand, comprises 14 communities. Its center of gravity is the city of Myrtle Beach, a centrally located entertainment hub. The region had the country‚Äôs  fastest-growing population of adults aged 65 and older [https://www.wsj.com/real-estate/luxury-homes/myrtle-beach-home-buyers-65-older-e949aa4c] between 2020 and 2023, up 23%, according to the U.S. Census Bureau.

BEYOND THE NEWSROOM

10

Buy Side from WSJ:  29 Best Gifts for Your Boss [https://www.wsj.com/buyside/gifts/gift-guides/gifts-for-boss]               

About Us

The 10-Point is your guide to The Wall Street Journal's reporting and analysis you can't get anywhere else. Your subscription makes our journalism possible.

Today's newsletter was curated and edited by Conor Grant and Gary Mitchell in collaboration with Editor in Chief Emma Tucker.

 Unsubscribe [http://www.wsj.com/newsletters?unsub=197&addr=0c1cf4e9510ef3deb662363d3efe06330da312d690e2ec5d1af9912eb7a9382eab6bb29a300547]      Unsubscribe https://10point.cmail19.com/t/d-u-seudyk-dhllatrhk-z/            Newsletters & Alerts [https://www.wsj.com/newsletters]            Contact Us [https://customercenter.wsj.com/public?url=https://customercenter.wsj.com/view/contactus.html]            Privacy Notice [https://dowjones.com/privacy-notice]            Cookie Notice [https://dowjones.com/cookie-notice]                             Dow Jones & Company, Inc. 4300 U.S. Ro‚Äåute 1 No‚Äårth Monm‚Äåouth Junc‚Äåtion, N‚ÄåJ 088‚Äå52

You are currently subscribed as matthewtershi@gmail.com. For further assistance, please contact Customer Service at support@wsj.com or 1-800-JOURNAL.

Copyright 2024 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.   |   All Rights Reserved.
